question: Question_01_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Short-Answer Questions}. Questions 1-4 are short-answer
questions. Put your answers in the boxes provided. \textbf{Simplify your
answers as much as possible, and show your work}. Each question is worth
3 marks, but not all questions are of equal difficulty.

Use a linear approximation to estimate $(2.001)^{4}$. Write your answer
in the form $n/1000$, where \emph{n} is an integer.
sols:
Let $f(x) = x^{4}$, so $f'(x) = 4x^{3}$. The linear approximation of
$f(x)$ at 2 is given by

\begin{align*}
L(x) &= f(2) + f'(2)(x-2) \\
&= 2^{4} + 4\cdot2^{3}(x-2)\\
&= 16 + 32(x-2)\end{align*}

Thus,
$(2.001)^{4} \approx L(2.001) = 16 + 32 \cdot(2.001-2) = 16 + \tfrac{32}{1000} = \tfrac{16032}{1000}$
hints:
There are two key questions we need to think about. Firstly, what would
be a good function to use to approximate $(2.001)^{4}$? Secondly, what
would be a good value to use as a linear approximation?

Try using the function $f(x) = x^{4}$ and the linear approximation
around the point $a=2$.
